awd_titl_txt: A bottom-up framework for the nanoscale origins of ice formation and adhesion on structured surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Icing is frequently encountered in nature and has adverse consequences on many human activities. Of particular importance is ice formation on rough surfaces, which are also chemically inhomogeneous. Surface roughness and composition drastically influence icing behavior, and consequently, ice adhesion, which is important for ice removal. By developing a better understanding of ice formation on realistic surfaces, appropriate steps can be taken to avert icing in situations where lives are threatened or when machines encounter trouble operating in freezing temperatures.  

The main goal of the work is to produce science-based guidelines for optimal anti-icing performance (maximum freezing delays and minimal ice adhesion). Using spectroscopic tools in conjunction with liquid-cell scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and in-situ cryo-cooling, the research examines icing on surfaces having nanoscale roughness and compositions from wettable to non-wettable. The methodology employs graphene liquid cells (GLCs) with encapsulated nanoparticles of varying wettabilities and sizes. The GLCs allow electron microscope (nm-scale resolution) dynamic observations of encapsulated nanoparticle suspensions in water, and with precise temperature control, they become vacuum-tight vessels for interrogating icing kinetics in real time. Ice formation is controlled by modulating the GLC sample temperature under various cooling scenarios. Parallel in-situ nanoscale spectroscopic methods quantify the ice/water mass ratio and structure around the nanoparticles during and after freezing, as a function of particle size, wettability and confinement in the atomically-thin-walled graphene cell. The macroscopic experiments, on the other hand, use surfaces with chemistry and characteristic length texture similar to the nanoscopic experiments, to determine macro freezing delays and ice adhesion strength. By correlating the macroscale ice properties with the nanoscale kinetic parameters, the project produces guidelines for optimal anti-icing performance or easy ice removal.  The research, by generating high-quality experimental data for a spatial regime of multiphase transport that has been inaccessible by existing instrumentation, also opens new horizons for validating and advancing models simulating nanometer-scale multiphase systems.

por.por_cntn:
Icing is frequently encountered in nature and has adverse, and sometimes life-threatening consequences for human activities. Of particular importance is ice formation on rough surfaces that are frequently found around us. Surface roughness and chemical composition drastically influence icing behavior, and consequently ice adhesion, which affects ice removal. The main goal of this work was to produce science-based guidelines for optimal anti-icing performance of solid surfaces. Using spectroscopic tools in conjunction with liquid-cell scanning transmission electron microscopy and in-situ cryo-cooling, the research examined icing on solids having nanoscale roughness and different chemical composition (and thus, wettability). The research developed a method where tiny amounts of water were encapsulated between graphene sheets (see first accompanying image), thus allowing real-time observations with nanometer resolution of ice formation in these nanoenclosures. The research produced experimental sequences showing dynamic ice crystal formation on or near nanoparticles contained in the cooled graphene liquids cells (see second accompanying image). Spectroscopic tools used in conjunction with electron microscopy provided new insight on the magnitude of pressure and density of water entrapped between graphene sheets and visualized in a scanning transmission electron microscope. Finally, the research revealed that the adhesion of ice that was formed from water that contained impurities differs considerably from the adhesion of pure ice. The results from this work provide the foundation for future studies that can help minimize damage and threat to life caused by icing events.
